_source.content: Hunter Biden‚Äôs defense team is weighed suing Fox News, Eric Trump, and Rudy Giuliani for defamation, according to a report.In a strategy conference call in September, attorney Kevin Morris told Hunter and others on the call that the president‚Äôs son should be taking a bold approach in the public eye to combat Republican investigations into the Biden family business, according to the Washington Post. The more aggressive tactics include potentially suing Fox News, Eric Trump, and Giuliani for defamation in relation to the contents of Hunter‚Äôs ‚ÄúLaptop from Hell.‚ÄùContents on the laptop, first reported by Breitbart News‚Äôs Political Editor Emma-Jo Morris, have revealed international business schemes on multiple continents while President Joe Biden was vice president and after he left office ‚Äî which have raised questions about the president‚Äôs influences on decision making.
_source.contentraw:
Hunter Biden‚Äôs defense team is weighed suing Fox News, Eric Trump, and Rudy Giuliani for defamation, according to a report.

In a strategy conference call in September, attorney Kevin Morris told Hunter and others on the call that the president‚Äôs son should be taking a bold approach in the public eye to combat Republican investigations into the Biden family business, according to the Washington Post. The more aggressive tactics include potentially suing Fox News, Eric Trump, and Giuliani for defamation in relation to the contents of Hunter‚Äôs ‚ÄúLaptop from Hell.‚Äù

Contents on the laptop, first reported by Breitbart News‚Äôs Political Editor Emma-Jo Morris, have revealed international business schemes on multiple continents while President Joe Biden was vice president and after he left office ‚Äî which have raised questions about the president‚Äôs influences on decision making.

_source.content: @Eric-Dubay The Nov 8 lunar eclipse is a curious rabbit hole. Perth and Montreal could see the eclipse at the same time - see screenshots below. From my understanding it may be possible to see the moon from the west coast of the US and the east coast of Australia - on a globe - but it's hard to believe we can see it from Montreal and Perth at the exact same time, no? I'm asking an honest question! Check out the time and date website for the detailed info and Google the photos - they were all over IG too! The other curious thing I noticed was the moon's markings. They seemed almost flipped. Like Perth was seeing one side of a disc and we were viewing the other side, flipped. I know you're busy, but it may be worth investigating the Nov 8 eclipse. Or maybe I'm just seeing things? What do you think?
_source.contentraw:

I'm asking an honest question! Check out the time and date website for the detailed info and Google the photos - they were all over IG too!

The other curious thing I noticed was the moon's markings. They seemed almost flipped. Like Perth was seeing one side of a disc and we were viewing the other side, flipped.

I know you're busy, but it may be worth investigating the Nov 8 eclipse. Or maybe I'm just seeing things?

What do you think?

_source.contentraw:
Fox News announced one shocking resignation that caught Donald Trump completely off guard

Fox News is the most-watched network on cable TV.

But no one expected this to happen.

And Fox News announced one shocking resignation that caught Donald Trump completely off guard.

Donald Trump‚Äôs decision to run for President in 2024 had an impact outside of politics.

It also led to Fox News making a change in its on-air talent, with the network announcing that Lara Trump‚Äôs position as a paid contributor was ending.

Fox News has a long-standing network policy that prohibits hiring anyone who is running for office or anyone with close ties to a political candidate.

Since Lara is married to Eric Trump, she is leaving now that Donald is officially in the race.

‚ÄúWe appreciate Lara‚Äôs valuable contributions across Fox News Media programming,‚Äù a Fox News spokesperson said in a statement to the Los Angeles Times.

Lara Trump, joined Fox News in March of 2021, has always been a staunch ally of her father-in-law in appearances on the network.

However, she hasn‚Äôt appeared on Fox News since Donald Trump declared himself a candidate for President on November 15.

Of course, Fox News owner Rupert Murdoch, who also owns the New York Post and The Wall Street Journal, recently announced that he was no longer supporting Donald Trump.

Murdoch is now backing Ron DeSantis in 2024.

The Murdoch-owned Post and Journal have openly criticized Trump and expressed opposition to him running for a second term.

As for Lara Trump, she previously served as a popular surrogate for Donald‚Äôs campaign in both 2016 and 2020, making appearances all across the country and rallying women voters behind her father-in-law.

Since Ivanka Trump and her husband Jared Kushner have decided not to play a role in the 2024 campaign to spend more time with their small children, Lara is likely to play an even bigger role for Donald Trump this time around.

She‚Äôs also teased the possibility of running for Congress.

In the past, she was rumored to be considering a run for the U.S. Senate in North Carolina.

Even though she decided not to run in the past, North Carolina has a gubernatorial election in 2024 and RINO Senator Thom Tillis is up for reelection in 2026.

Lara Trump has a lot of opportunities as she prepares to join her father-in-law‚Äôs campaign and try to help him win another term as President.

(Don't count on it!)

‚ÄúAnd if that means we need to defund portions of DHS, if that means that we need to take away their federal authority in various areas, we ought to do it, and certainly Mayorkas ought to be impeached.‚Äù

The idea behind having a Department of Homeland Security was to protect the country from foreign adversaries. That‚Äôs not what DHS is doing under Biden, Hawley notes.

‚ÄúThey are not after foreign adversaries,‚Äù Hawley argues. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre after Americans. Their own internal documents, that we have now seen, show that they are targeting domestic speech by American citizens. That‚Äôs what makes it so grossly unconstitutional.‚Äù

As for Senate Republicans‚Äô decision to retain Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Kentucky, as their leader, neither Hawley nor Missouri Sen.-elect Eric Schmitt wanted McConnell kept on. Asked at a pre-election rally for Schmitt who should be that leader, Hawley said, ‚Äúnot Mitch McConnell.‚Äù

‚ÄúI voted no on that,‚Äù Hawley said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been very clear. I did not support him for leader.

‚ÄúI hope that we see a change in course. I don‚Äôt know that we will."

There will never be any change. Censorship is the cornerstone of the US government. It can't survive without it.

http://heartlandernews.com/2022/11/17/biden-administration-still-out-to-censor-its-critics-on-facebook-instagram-and-other-social-media-missouri-sen-hawley-warns

_source.content: Part 2The new tool was announced on Dec. 10, 2020, when ‚ÄúTrump was in the middle of firing off 25 tweets saying things like, ‚ÄòA coup is taking place in front of our eyes,‚Äô‚Äù Taibbi wrote.The Twitter enforcement team‚Äôs messages showed they sometimes adjusted their moderation actions when the targeted tweets were critical of the censorship itself.In one instance, Rep. Jody Hice (R-Ga.) posted a tweet sharing a message that had been blocked when shared by another account‚Äî‚ÄùMailed ballots are more prone to fraud than in-person voting. That shouldn‚Äôt be controversial. It‚Äôs just common sense.‚ÄùSharing that message, Hice said that Twitter ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt want you to see this tweet‚Äù and added, ‚ÄúSay NO to Big Tech censorship.‚ÄùOne of the Twitter staffers considering action on Hice‚Äôs post acknowledges that his message about there being more fraud with mail-in ballots than with in-person ballots ‚Äúis much more of a legitimate statement even if scale is minuscule‚Äù and suggests applying a ‚Äúsoft intervention.‚ÄùRoth replies, ‚ÄúAgree‚Äù before cautioning that going ‚Äútoo far down the rabbit hole of labeling critical speech (i.e. critical of our handling of this case) is dangerous.‚Äù‚ÄúIt becomes a self-reinforcing ‚Äòwah wah censorship‚Äô cycle,‚Äù Roth added.Soft on BidenBy contrast, there were multiple instances in which pro-Biden tweets warning that Trump ‚Äúmay try to steal the election‚Äù were flagged for possible action, only for Twitter executives to give them the green light.In one such case, a user shared a news report about Supreme Court Justice John Roberts swearing in newly-appointed Justice Amy Coney Barrett, claiming in the comment that ‚Äúthey‚Äôre going to try to steal the election‚Äù and urging people ‚Äúif you haven‚Äôt voted yet ‚Äì don‚Äôt mail. drop it off or vote early.‚ÄùA Twitter staffer asked the team to weigh in, calling it an ‚Äúedge case‚Äù with commentary encouraging voters not to vote by mail and that ‚ÄúI believe we should label it.‚ÄùAn executive dismissed the recommendation, saying the tweet is ‚Äústill encouraging people to vote, but expresses the concern that mailed ballots might not make it in time,‚Äù which ‚Äúseems fair.‚ÄùIn another case, a tweet claiming Trump and Barrett would steal the election was flagged for possible labeling. A Twitter executive decided not to, saying the employee‚Äôs concern was ‚Äúunderstandable‚Äù but the tweet seemed to be in reference to a Supreme Court decision on processing mail-in ballots that arrive after Election Day.Roth also ordered a label to be overturned that had been applied to a tweet from former Attorney General Eric Holder, who claimed that the U.S. Postal Service had been ‚Äúdeliberately crippled.‚Äù‚ÄúEverything in it is factually accurate,‚Äù Roth wrote, with a Twitter staffer then announcing the label had been removed.Also, screengrabs of internal messages revealed that after Twitter executives banned Trump from the platform, they discussed banning future presidents, with one executive noting that then-incoming President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration ‚Äúwill not be suspended by Twitter unless absolutely necessary.‚Äù‚ÄòFederal Election Commission Violations‚Äô?Commenting on the latest Twitter Files revelations, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich told The Epoch Times in an interview that the platform‚Äôs behind-scenes operation to suppress certain viewpoints is ‚Äúpretty horrifying‚Äù and shows Twitter was part of the effort to interfere in the 2020 presidential election.‚ÄúIf you take the president of the United States off of Twitter, what did that cost? If you are Google, and in the last four days of every month, you refuse to deliver Republican fundraising emails, what does that cost?‚Äù Gingrich said, referring to Trump‚Äôs Twitter ban and allegations that Google had filtered millions of the Republican National Committee‚Äôs political campaign emails to spam folders at the end of each month.‚ÄúThese things should be considered federal election commission violations, because they are actions by a corporation to reshape the election,‚Äù Gingrich argued.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pretty amazing story of censorship in a country which is dedicated to the First Amendment right of free speech,‚Äù he said.Gingrich believes that major social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter have become so integrated with people‚Äôs lives that they should be considered public utilities, and regulated as such.The Epoch Times has reached out to Twitter for comment.Caden Pearson and Eva Fu contributed to this report
_source.contentraw:
Part 2

The new tool was announced on Dec. 10, 2020, when ‚ÄúTrump was in the middle of firing off 25 tweets saying things like, ‚ÄòA coup is taking place in front of our eyes,‚Äô‚Äù Taibbi wrote.

The Twitter enforcement team‚Äôs messages showed they sometimes adjusted their moderation actions when the targeted tweets were critical of the censorship itself.

In one instance, Rep. Jody Hice (R-Ga.) posted a tweet sharing a message that had been blocked when shared by another account‚Äî‚ÄùMailed ballots are more prone to fraud than in-person voting. That shouldn‚Äôt be controversial. It‚Äôs just common sense.‚Äù

Sharing that message, Hice said that Twitter ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt want you to see this tweet‚Äù and added, ‚ÄúSay NO to Big Tech censorship.‚Äù

One of the Twitter staffers considering action on Hice‚Äôs post acknowledges that his message about there being more fraud with mail-in ballots than with in-person ballots ‚Äúis much more of a legitimate statement even if scale is minuscule‚Äù and suggests applying a ‚Äúsoft intervention.‚Äù

Roth replies, ‚ÄúAgree‚Äù before cautioning that going ‚Äútoo far down the rabbit hole of labeling critical speech (i.e. critical of our handling of this case) is dangerous.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt becomes a self-reinforcing ‚Äòwah wah censorship‚Äô cycle,‚Äù Roth added.

Soft on Biden

By contrast, there were multiple instances in which pro-Biden tweets warning that Trump ‚Äúmay try to steal the election‚Äù were flagged for possible action, only for Twitter executives to give them the green light.

In one such case, a user shared a news report about Supreme Court Justice John Roberts swearing in newly-appointed Justice Amy Coney Barrett, claiming in the comment that ‚Äúthey‚Äôre going to try to steal the election‚Äù and urging people ‚Äúif you haven‚Äôt voted yet ‚Äì don‚Äôt mail. drop it off or vote early.‚Äù

A Twitter staffer asked the team to weigh in, calling it an ‚Äúedge case‚Äù with commentary encouraging voters not to vote by mail and that ‚ÄúI believe we should label it.‚Äù

An executive dismissed the recommendation, saying the tweet is ‚Äústill encouraging people to vote, but expresses the concern that mailed ballots might not make it in time,‚Äù which ‚Äúseems fair.‚Äù

In another case, a tweet claiming Trump and Barrett would steal the election was flagged for possible labeling. A Twitter executive decided not to, saying the employee‚Äôs concern was ‚Äúunderstandable‚Äù but the tweet seemed to be in reference to a Supreme Court decision on processing mail-in ballots that arrive after Election Day.

Roth also ordered a label to be overturned that had been applied to a tweet from former Attorney General Eric Holder, who claimed that the U.S. Postal Service had been ‚Äúdeliberately crippled.‚Äù

‚ÄúEverything in it is factually accurate,‚Äù Roth wrote, with a Twitter staffer then announcing the label had been removed.

Also, screengrabs of internal messages revealed that after Twitter executives banned Trump from the platform, they discussed banning future presidents, with one executive noting that then-incoming President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration ‚Äúwill not be suspended by Twitter unless absolutely necessary.‚Äù

‚ÄòFederal Election Commission Violations‚Äô?

Commenting on the latest Twitter Files revelations, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich told The Epoch Times in an interview that the platform‚Äôs behind-scenes operation to suppress certain viewpoints is ‚Äúpretty horrifying‚Äù and shows Twitter was part of the effort to interfere in the 2020 presidential election.

‚ÄúIf you take the president of the United States off of Twitter, what did that cost? If you are Google, and in the last four days of every month, you refuse to deliver Republican fundraising emails, what does that cost?‚Äù Gingrich said, referring to Trump‚Äôs Twitter ban and allegations that Google had filtered millions of the Republican National Committee‚Äôs political campaign emails to spam folders at the end of each month.

‚ÄúThese things should be considered federal election commission violations, because they are actions by a corporation to reshape the election,‚Äù Gingrich argued.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pretty amazing story of censorship in a country which is dedicated to the First Amendment right of free speech,‚Äù he said.

Gingrich believes that major social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter have become so integrated with people‚Äôs lives that they should be considered public utilities, and regulated as such.

The Epoch Times has reached out to Twitter for comment.

Caden Pearson and Eva Fu contributed to this report

card.title: Hunter Biden's Strategy To Go On The Offensive Indicts The Feds

_source.content: Hunter Biden‚Äôs Strategy To Go On The Offensive Further Indicts The FedsA strangely timed DEA raid, whistleblower claims, and other red flags raise new questions about Hunter Biden and his family affairs.Two months after the FBI subpoenaed the laptop Hunter Biden had abandoned at a Delaware computer repair store, the Drug Enforcement Administration searched the office of Hunter‚Äôs one-time psychiatrist Keith Ablow and seized a second laptop Hunter had left with him. The timing of the DEA raid and the fact that criminal charges were never filed against Ablow, coupled with whistleblowers‚Äô claims that the FBI buried evidence against Hunter Biden, raises the question of whether the search was a pretext to recover Hunter‚Äôs laptop and protect the Biden family. While the DEA‚Äôs recovery of the second Hunter Biden laptop escaped scrutiny over the last nearly three years, a Washington Post article from Saturday brings that laptop into focus ‚Äî and with it questions about the DEA‚Äôs seizure of the laptop and agents‚Äô decision to return it to Hunter. In a weekend article titled ‚ÄúSome Hunter Biden Allies Making Plans to go After His Accusers,‚Äù The Washington Post reported that Hunter and his closest advisers are plotting an offensive for when Republicans assume control of the House of Representatives in January. The strategy sessions to counter what Biden associates frame as ‚Äúan expected onslaught of investigations by House Republicans‚Äù began last September, according to the Post, with a meeting at the California home of Hunter Biden‚Äôs friend and lawyer Kevin Morris. Morris, already famous in the entertainment industry as an attorney for the co-creators of ‚ÄúSouth Park,‚Äù gained notoriety when the New York Post reported that Morris ‚Äúfooted Hunter Biden‚Äôs overdue taxes totaling over $2 million.‚Äù In addition to Morris, David Brock, a liberal activist, reportedly joined in the September 2022 strategy session. ‚ÄúAt one point, Hunter Biden himself happened to call into the meeting, connecting briefly by video to add his own thoughts,‚Äù according to the Post. While not detailing Hunter‚Äôs purported thoughts, The Washington Post reported that Morris suggested ‚Äúit was crucial‚Äù ‚Äúfor Hunter Biden‚Äôs camp to be more aggressive.‚Äù According to Saturday‚Äôs article, Morris then described during the September meeting at his California home the ‚Äúdefamation lawsuits the team could pursue against the presidential son‚Äôs critics, including Fox News, Eric Trump and Rudy Giuliani.‚Äù Morris also reportedly ‚Äúoutlined extensive research on two potential witnesses against Hunter Biden ‚Äî a spurned business partner named Tony Bobulinski and a computer repairman named John Paul Mac Isaac.‚ÄùBrock provided more insight, telling the Post: ‚ÄúThey feel that there is a whole counternarrative missing because of the whole Hunter-hater narrative out there.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat we really got into was more the meat of it, the meat of what a response would look like,‚Äù Brock said of the September meeting. To aid the efforts, Brock planned to start a new group ‚Äî since launched ‚Äî named Facts First USA, which Brock described as a ‚ÄúSWAT team‚Äù designed to ‚Äúensure that the media and public do not accept the false narratives that flows from congressional investigations.‚ÄùMore recently, according to the Post, ‚ÄúBrock‚Äôs group, Facts First, is engaging with Hunter Biden and those in his immediate circle.‚Äù Brock is reportedly ‚Äúreviewing research that Morris has conducted on Biden‚Äôs adversaries, including Bobulinski and Mac Isaac.‚Äù According to The Washington Post, Morris and others are also focused on whether the data claimed to be recovered from the laptop Hunter Biden abandoned at the Delaware computer repair store, ‚Äúwas improperly obtained and distributed,‚Äù with Hunter and his allies suggesting that the materials released by Giuliani and others may not have originated from the laptop Hunter abandoned at the repair shop. Instead, the help-Hunter crew posits that the information may have been improperly taken from a laptop Hunter left with Ablow, whom the Post frames as ‚Äúclose to Republican activist Roger Stone.‚Äù The Post then reported that ‚ÄúMorris has been overseeing a forensic analysis of that laptop to determine if it was the basis of the hard drives that were later distributed by Trump allies.‚Äù Morris began floating a similar tangled conspiracy theory in May 2022, with CBS News reporting, ‚ÄúMorris and his team have been circulating provocative slides that tease a coming counter-narrative to political attacks against the president‚Äôs son.‚Äù The slides describe a ‚Äúcontextualized theory‚Äù positing that ‚Äúthere was no laptop dropped off with Mac Isaac, just a laptop which Hunter abandoned on Feb. 1, 2019, at the office of his psychiatrist, Dr. Keith Ablow.‚Äù A lot more: Keep reading.https://thefederalist.com/2022/12/12/did-the-dea-raid-hunter-bidens-former-shrink-to-scoop-up-a-second-laptop/
_source.contentraw:
Hunter Biden‚Äôs Strategy To Go On The Offensive Further Indicts The Feds

A strangely timed DEA raid, whistleblower claims, and other red flags raise new questions about Hunter Biden and his family affairs.

Two months after the FBI subpoenaed the laptop Hunter Biden had abandoned at a Delaware computer repair store, the Drug Enforcement Administration searched the office of Hunter‚Äôs one-time psychiatrist Keith Ablow and seized a second laptop Hunter had left with him. The timing of the DEA raid and the fact that criminal charges were never filed against Ablow, coupled with whistleblowers‚Äô claims that the FBI buried evidence against Hunter Biden, raises the question of whether the search was a pretext to recover Hunter‚Äôs laptop and protect the Biden family.

While the DEA‚Äôs recovery of the second Hunter Biden laptop escaped scrutiny over the last nearly three years, a Washington Post article from Saturday brings that laptop into focus ‚Äî and with it questions about the DEA‚Äôs seizure of the laptop and agents‚Äô decision to return it to Hunter.

In a weekend article titled ‚ÄúSome Hunter Biden Allies Making Plans to go After His Accusers,‚Äù The Washington Post reported that Hunter and his closest advisers are plotting an offensive for when Republicans assume control of the House of Representatives in January. The strategy sessions to counter what Biden associates frame as ‚Äúan expected onslaught of investigations by House Republicans‚Äù began last September, according to the Post, with a meeting at the California home of Hunter Biden‚Äôs friend and lawyer Kevin Morris.

Morris, already famous in the entertainment industry as an attorney for the co-creators of ‚ÄúSouth Park,‚Äù gained notoriety when the New York Post reported that Morris ‚Äúfooted Hunter Biden‚Äôs overdue taxes totaling over $2 million.‚Äù In addition to Morris, David Brock, a liberal activist, reportedly joined in the September 2022 strategy session. ‚ÄúAt one point, Hunter Biden himself happened to call into the meeting, connecting briefly by video to add his own thoughts,‚Äù according to the Post.

While not detailing Hunter‚Äôs purported thoughts, The Washington Post reported that Morris suggested ‚Äúit was crucial‚Äù ‚Äúfor Hunter Biden‚Äôs camp to be more aggressive.‚Äù According to Saturday‚Äôs article, Morris then described during the September meeting at his California home the ‚Äúdefamation lawsuits the team could pursue against the presidential son‚Äôs critics, including Fox News, Eric Trump and Rudy Giuliani.‚Äù Morris also reportedly ‚Äúoutlined extensive research on two potential witnesses against Hunter Biden ‚Äî a spurned business partner named Tony Bobulinski and a computer repairman named John Paul Mac Isaac.‚Äù

Brock provided more insight, telling the Post: ‚ÄúThey feel that there is a whole counternarrative missing because of the whole Hunter-hater narrative out there.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat we really got into was more the meat of it, the meat of what a response would look like,‚Äù Brock said of the September meeting. To aid the efforts, Brock planned to start a new group ‚Äî since launched ‚Äî named Facts First USA, which Brock described as a ‚ÄúSWAT team‚Äù designed to ‚Äúensure that the media and public do not accept the false narratives that flows from congressional investigations.‚Äù

More recently, according to the Post, ‚ÄúBrock‚Äôs group, Facts First, is engaging with Hunter Biden and those in his immediate circle.‚Äù Brock is reportedly ‚Äúreviewing research that Morris has conducted on Biden‚Äôs adversaries, including Bobulinski and Mac Isaac.‚Äù

According to The Washington Post, Morris and others are also focused on whether the data claimed to be recovered from the laptop Hunter Biden abandoned at the Delaware computer repair store, ‚Äúwas improperly obtained and distributed,‚Äù with Hunter and his allies suggesting that the materials released by Giuliani and others may not have originated from the laptop Hunter abandoned at the repair shop. Instead, the help-Hunter crew posits that the information may have been improperly taken from a laptop Hunter left with Ablow, whom the Post frames as ‚Äúclose to Republican activist Roger Stone.‚Äù The Post then reported that ‚ÄúMorris has been overseeing a forensic analysis of that laptop to determine if it was the basis of the hard drives that were later distributed by Trump allies.‚Äù

Morris began floating a similar tangled conspiracy theory in May 2022, with CBS News reporting, ‚ÄúMorris and his team have been circulating provocative slides that tease a coming counter-narrative to political attacks against the president‚Äôs son.‚Äù The slides describe a ‚Äúcontextualized theory‚Äù positing that ‚Äúthere was no laptop dropped off with Mac Isaac, just a laptop which Hunter abandoned on Feb. 1, 2019, at the office of his psychiatrist, Dr. Keith Ablow.‚Äù

A lot more: Keep reading.

_source.content: 'Morris, at the meeting in his California home, described defamation lawsuits the team could pursue against the presidential son‚Äôs critics, including Fox News, Eric Trump and Rudy Giuliani. He outlined extensive research on two potential witnesses against Hunter Biden ‚Äî a spurned business partner named Tony Bobulinski and a computer repairman named John Paul Mac Isaac.At one point, Hunter Biden himself happened to call into the meeting, connecting briefly by video to add his own thoughts.‚ÄúThey feel that there is a whole counternarrative missing because of the whole Hunter-hater narrative out there,‚Äù said liberal activist David Brock, who attended the meeting. ‚ÄúWhat we really got into was more the meat of it, the meat of what a response would look like.‚Äù Brock was planning for a new group, Facts First USA, focused on fighting the looming House GOP investigations.The meeting was a glimpse into a sprawling infrastructure that is rapidly, almost frantically, assembling to combat Republicans‚Äô plans to turn Hunter Biden into a major news story when the GOP takes over the House next year. The risk for Hunter Biden, and possibly for President Biden as well, is that this hodgepodge of efforts is not fully coordinating and does not share a unified approach, according to people involved in the effort who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal dynamics.Hunter Biden has been working with Morris, his friend and sometime financial benefactor, and a team of researchers. The younger Biden has also hired several other lawyers ‚Äî Chris Clark, who is handling a federal criminal investigation into his business dealings and other matters, along with a separate attorney, Joshua A. Levy, to deal directly with the House investigators.Meanwhile, the White House and the Democratic National Committee have developed their own strategies for dealing with what could be a political firestorm around the president‚Äôs son. Bob Bauer, a former White House counsel under President Barack Obama, is set to represent President Biden in a personal capacity should the need arise. And a trio of Democratic-aligned outside groups has stepped up to provide rapid response and other communications.But these various efforts are not always coordinating, and several people involved expressed concern about the aggressive tack suggested by Morris, who wants to elevate Hunter Biden‚Äôs public role.Morris, a Hollywood lawyer and novelist who has worked with celebrity clients and the creators of television‚Äôs ‚ÄúSouth Park,‚Äù befriended Hunter Biden in 2019, when the president‚Äôs son was by his own account recovering from a serious drug addiction. Morris has already attracted the attention of House Republicans, who sent him a letter in June asking about reports that he gave Hunter Biden some $2 million to help pay off a tax bill that is a subject of the federal investigation.Some involved in these efforts argue that Hunter Biden and Morris should stay out of the limelight so Democrats can focus on painting the Republican investigations as a partisan political exercise. ‚ÄúNo one thinks this strategy of putting Hunter Biden front and center is smart,‚Äù said one Democrat involved in the broader effort, who requested anonymity to describe private conversations. ‚ÄúNo one, including the White House, thinks this is a smart strategy.‚ÄùThe division is in part between associates of Hunter Biden, who tend to favor a more aggressive strategy, and other strategists who want him to keep a lower profile. Sources close to Hunter Biden emphasized that they are operating separately from the White House. Brock said his organization also remains independent of Hunter Biden and his team and is following its own strategy.For the White House, the overriding message is that Hunter Biden is clearly a private citizen and an inappropriate target for Congress to investigate, and that Republicans are more concerned with pursuing conspiracies than solving the country‚Äôs problems.‚ÄúThe president loves his son and is proud that he has overcome his addiction and is moving forward with his life,‚Äù said Ian Sams, a White House spokesman handling the upcoming House investigations. ‚ÄúCongressional Republicans‚Äô politically motivated partisan attacks on the president and his family are rooted in nonsensical conspiracy theories and do nothing to address the real issues Americans care about.‚ÄùWhite House officials have previously said they plan to minimize their cooperation with investigations like the Hunter Biden inquiry that they view as politically motivated, while honoring GOP-led probes on more substantive topics like the U.S. pullout from Afghanistan.In the meantime, Hunter Biden, who has not commented on the inquiries for months while under Justice Department investigation, has been taking on a more prominent public role in recent weeks. He has appeared at a number of White House events, at times with his 2-year-old son Beau.'https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/12/10/hunter-biden-plans-defense/
_source.contentraw:
'Morris, at the meeting in his California home, described defamation lawsuits the team could pursue against the presidential son‚Äôs critics, including Fox News, Eric Trump and Rudy Giuliani. He outlined extensive research on two potential witnesses against Hunter Biden ‚Äî a spurned business partner named Tony Bobulinski and a computer repairman named John Paul Mac Isaac.

At one point, Hunter Biden himself happened to call into the meeting, connecting briefly by video to add his own thoughts.

‚ÄúThey feel that there is a whole counternarrative missing because of the whole Hunter-hater narrative out there,‚Äù said liberal activist David Brock, who attended the meeting. ‚ÄúWhat we really got into was more the meat of it, the meat of what a response would look like.‚Äù Brock was planning for a new group, Facts First USA, focused on fighting the looming House GOP investigations.

The meeting was a glimpse into a sprawling infrastructure that is rapidly, almost frantically, assembling to combat Republicans‚Äô plans to turn Hunter Biden into a major news story when the GOP takes over the House next year. The risk for Hunter Biden, and possibly for President Biden as well, is that this hodgepodge of efforts is not fully coordinating and does not share a unified approach, according to people involved in the effort who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal dynamics.

Hunter Biden has been working with Morris, his friend and sometime financial benefactor, and a team of researchers. The younger Biden has also hired several other lawyers ‚Äî Chris Clark, who is handling a federal criminal investigation into his business dealings and other matters, along with a separate attorney, Joshua A. Levy, to deal directly with the House investigators.

Meanwhile, the White House and the Democratic National Committee have developed their own strategies for dealing with what could be a political firestorm around the president‚Äôs son. Bob Bauer, a former White House counsel under President Barack Obama, is set to represent President Biden in a personal capacity should the need arise. And a trio of Democratic-aligned outside groups has stepped up to provide rapid response and other communications.

But these various efforts are not always coordinating, and several people involved expressed concern about the aggressive tack suggested by Morris, who wants to elevate Hunter Biden‚Äôs public role.

Morris, a Hollywood lawyer and novelist who has worked with celebrity clients and the creators of television‚Äôs ‚ÄúSouth Park,‚Äù befriended Hunter Biden in 2019, when the president‚Äôs son was by his own account recovering from a serious drug addiction. Morris has already attracted the attention of House Republicans, who sent him a letter in June asking about reports that he gave Hunter Biden some $2 million to help pay off a tax bill that is a subject of the federal investigation.

Some involved in these efforts argue that Hunter Biden and Morris should stay out of the limelight so Democrats can focus on painting the Republican investigations as a partisan political exercise. ‚ÄúNo one thinks this strategy of putting Hunter Biden front and center is smart,‚Äù said one Democrat involved in the broader effort, who requested anonymity to describe private conversations. ‚ÄúNo one, including the White House, thinks this is a smart strategy.‚Äù

The division is in part between associates of Hunter Biden, who tend to favor a more aggressive strategy, and other strategists who want him to keep a lower profile. Sources close to Hunter Biden emphasized that they are operating separately from the White House. Brock said his organization also remains independent of Hunter Biden and his team and is following its own strategy.

For the White House, the overriding message is that Hunter Biden is clearly a private citizen and an inappropriate target for Congress to investigate, and that Republicans are more concerned with pursuing conspiracies than solving the country‚Äôs problems.

‚ÄúThe president loves his son and is proud that he has overcome his addiction and is moving forward with his life,‚Äù said Ian Sams, a White House spokesman handling the upcoming House investigations. ‚ÄúCongressional Republicans‚Äô politically motivated partisan attacks on the president and his family are rooted in nonsensical conspiracy theories and do nothing to address the real issues Americans care about.‚Äù

White House officials have previously said they plan to minimize their cooperation with investigations like the Hunter Biden inquiry that they view as politically motivated, while honoring GOP-led probes on more substantive topics like the U.S. pullout from Afghanistan.

In the meantime, Hunter Biden, who has not commented on the inquiries for months while under Justice Department investigation, has been taking on a more prominent public role in recent weeks. He has appeared at a number of White House events, at times with his 2-year-old son Beau.'

https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/12/10/hunter-biden-plans-defense/

card.description: The White House is shelling out $265,000 a year in salary for staff whose primary portfolio will be to run comms and defense for the administration from an approaching blizzard of subpoenas.
card.title: White House spending $265K on staff to deflect Hunter Biden probe

quote.content:
'The White House is gearing up for a growing army of staff to fend off potential Republican-led probes on everything from Hunter Biden to the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan ‚Äî and TAXPAYERS ARE FOOTING THE BILL.

In May, the White House poached Richard A. Sauber, the top attorney for the Department of Veterans Affairs, to serve as a ‚Äúdeputy counsel to the president‚Äù tasked with handling House oversight probes. Ian Sams, a veteran of Vice President Harris‚Äô failed 2020 presidential campaign, was hired to run official comms for the team. White House records show the two men will take home $155,000 and $110,000 respectively.

And the team is only expected to grow, the Washington Post reported ‚Äî indicating that its staffing and operational expenditures will balloon further.'

https://nypost.com/2022/10/08/white-house-spending-265k-to-deflect-hunter-biden-probe/
